meanings.definition: Used to introduce a phrase or clause contrasting with what has already been mentioned.
meanings.sent1: She wanted to go to the park, but it started raining.
meanings.sent2: I like ice cream, but I don't like chocolate.
meanings.sent3: He was excited to play outside, but the thunderstorm ruined his plans.
meanings.sent4: Her smile was bright, but her eyes told a different story.
meanings.sent5: The book was thin, but its content was profound.

meanings.sent1: Everyone was invited to the party but John.
meanings.sent2: I like all fruits but bananas.
meanings.sent3: The store had everything but the item I needed.
meanings.sent4: The garden was full of flowers but one lonely rose.
meanings.sent5: The room was empty but for a single chair.

meanings.sent1: She thought he was angry, but he was actually laughing.
meanings.sent2: The day seemed dull, but the sunset was breathtaking.
meanings.sent3: He looked tired, but he danced all night.
meanings.sent4: The movie appeared boring, but it turned out to be exciting.
meanings.sent5: The room felt cold, but the fireplace warmed it up quickly.
